title: POSSE - IndieWeb
description_html: is an abbreviation for Publish (on your) Own Site, Syndicate Elsewhere, a content publishing model that starts with posting content on your own domain first, then syndicating out copies to 3rd party services with permashortlinks back to the original on your site.
description: is an abbreviation for Publish (on your) Own Site, Syndicate Elsewhere, a content publishing model that starts with posting content on your own domain first, then syndicating out copies to 3rd party services with permashortlinks back to the original on your site.

title: Photos - macwright.org
description_html:
"I don’t like Instagram. I know that other people like it: they found a community there. They keep in touch with family. They share interests and life events. But I just don’t: I don’t like how browsing Instagram makes me feel. I don’t like how it shapes my photos, how it works as a product. I don’t like that it’s a Facebook company. How it doesn’t have critical APIs. You can’t cross-post to Instagram without using the app.

By creating my own place to post photography, I can start to like taking photos again. I can feel like my process of taking film photos, scanning them, and putting them on the web is worthwhile. "
description:
"I don’t like Instagram. I know that other people like it: they found a community there. They keep in touch with family. They share interests and life events. But I just don’t: I don’t like how browsing Instagram makes me feel. I don’t like how it shapes my photos, how it works as a product. I don’t like that it’s a Facebook company. How it doesn’t have critical APIs. You can’t cross-post to Instagram without using the app.

By creating my own place to post photography, I can start to like taking photos again. I can feel like my process of taking film photos, scanning them, and putting them on the web is worthwhile. "

title: Where to Draw the Line on Deplatforming
generated_title: Where to Draw the Line on Deplatforming
description_html: "While it’s refreshing to see technology companies act swiftly to protect their users, in this case it’s also unsettling. Internet providers operate at a layer above websites, users, and even many infrastructural parts of the web. Many may argue that Facebook shouldn’t referee speech at all, but it’s clear to everyone that Facebook is within its rights to decide what conversations happen there. That’s why so many now make the persuasive case that it can do a better job moderating those conversations—which isn’t censorship. But it is censorship when ISPs, which are merely gateways to those conversations, try to take on hate speech or other content themselves. We don’t want ISPs making those calls."
description: "While it’s refreshing to see technology companies act swiftly to protect their users, in this case it’s also unsettling. Internet providers operate at a layer above websites, users, and even many infrastructural parts of the web. Many may argue that Facebook shouldn’t referee speech at all, but it’s clear to everyone that Facebook is within its rights to decide what conversations happen there. That’s why so many now make the persuasive case that it can do a better job moderating those conversations—which isn’t censorship. But it is censorship when ISPs, which are merely gateways to those conversations, try to take on hate speech or other content themselves. We don’t want ISPs making those calls."

source.title: ISPs Were Wrong to Block 8chan After the New Zealand Shooting

title: The Crypto Anarchist Manifesto
description_html: Here's the "Crypto Anarchist Manifesto" I read at the September 1992 founding meeting. It dates back to mid-1988 and was distributed to some like-minded techno-anarchists at the "Crypto '88" conference and then again at the "Hackers Conference" that year. I later gave talks at Hackers on this in 1989 and 1990.
description: Here's the "Crypto Anarchist Manifesto" I read at the September 1992 founding meeting. It dates back to mid-1988 and was distributed to some like-minded techno-anarchists at the "Crypto '88" conference and then again at the "Hackers Conference" that year. I later gave talks at Hackers on this in 1989 and 1990.

content_html: In the long run, making programs free is a step toward the post-scarcity world, where nobody will have to work very hard just to make a living. People will be free to devote themselves to activities that are fun, such as programming, after spending the necessary ten hours a week on required tasks such as legislation, family counseling, robot repair and asteroid prospecting. There will be no need to be able to make a living from programming.
content: In the long run, making programs free is a step toward the post-scarcity world, where nobody will have to work very hard just to make a living. People will be free to devote themselves to activities that are fun, such as programming, after spending the necessary ten hours a week on required tasks such as legislation, family counseling, robot repair and asteroid prospecting. There will be no need to be able to make a living from programming.

content_html:
• Access to computers-and anything that might teach you something about the way the world works-should be unlimited and total.
  • All information should be free.
  • Hackers should be judged by their hacking, not bogus criteria such as degrees, age, race, or position.
  • You can create art and beauty on a computer.
  • Computers can change your life for the better.
content:
- Access to computers-and anything that might teach you something about the way the world works-should be unlimited and total.
- All information should be free.
- Hackers should be judged by their hacking, not bogus criteria such as degrees, age, race, or position.
- You can create art and beauty on a computer.
- Computers can change your life for the better.

title: Josh Sternberg on Twitter
description_html: Theory: Appliances have gotten worse because of technology. Oven repairman to us: "they're all shitty because the computer boards all die." So we spend more on appliances than in the past, which leads to more profits for companies and less money for consumers.
description: Theory: Appliances have gotten worse because of technology. Oven repairman to us: "they're all shitty because the computer boards all die." So we spend more on appliances than in the past, which leads to more profits for companies and less money for consumers.

title: Nowpages - Daniel Bachhuber
description_html: Personal email newsletters are a trend in the right direction. They're often the right combination of content (summarized update) and frequency (once/week). But, email doesn't scale, in as so far as I can't imagine subscribing to hundreds of personal newsletters. It would be neat if there was an app where you could see summarized updates ...

title: Static Indieweb pt2: Using Webmentions
description_html: In last week's post, I talked about syndicating content from a static site to Twitter. But getting content out is only half the challenge. The real value of social media (apart from the massive ad revenue and dystopian data mining) is in the reactions we get from other people.

title: dogsheep/dogsheep-photos
description_html: Save details of your photos to a SQLite database and upload them to S3. See Using SQL to find my best photo of a pelican according to Apple Photos for background information on this project. These tools are a work-in-progress mechanism for taking full ownership of your photos.

title: Clay Shirky: How the Internet will (one day) transform government
generated_title: Clay Shirky: How the Internet will (one day) transform government
description_html: The open-source world has learned to deal with a flood of new, oftentimes divergent, ideas using hosting services like GitHub -- so why can't governments? In this rousing talk Clay Shirky shows how democracies can take a lesson from the Internet, to be not just transparent but also to draw on the knowledge of all their citizens.
description: The open-source world has learned to deal with a flood of new, oftentimes divergent, ideas using hosting services like GitHub -- so why can't governments? In this rousing talk Clay Shirky shows how democracies can take a lesson from the Internet, to be not just transparent but also to draw on the knowledge of all their citizens.

source.title: Clay Shirky: How the Internet will (one day) transform government

title: Why Developers Should Archive Their Old Content
generated_title: Why Developers Should Archive Their Old Content
description_html: Archiving content, especially content that has been published on an external website, helps us ensure that we can keep an accurate record of our writing and that we’re never caught by surprise if our content is removed or deprecated by a publisher.
description: Archiving content, especially content that has been published on an external website, helps us ensure that we can keep an accurate record of our writing and that we’re never caught by surprise if our content is removed or deprecated by a publisher.
